data:
{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2985205,"name":"Gregory S. ","username":"Gregory78","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gregory78/{size}/73219_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-05T03:23:59.388Z","cooked":"

Team 78 Air Strike has been working on designing and manufacturing some mule chassis during the 2021 offseason. This project gave us a chance to get more people involved in learning OnShape and cad in general, end up with chassis that would be used for prototype testing and programming during the build season, and allow us to try some design solutions we haven’t before.

For some background, we wanted to make the chassis as flexible as possible, within reason, and based around the COTS items we prefer. We also designing these around our manufacturing ability and what we think is worth spending time on making and what isn’t. Each chassis was designed to use WCP single speed gearboxes (the 2 motor flipped and 3 motor non flipped) with as many mount locations as possible, custom bearing blocks, 6 or 8 wheel drive options, and getting the wheels as far into the corners as possible.

The 4" Wheel Chassis

Screen Shot 2022-01-04 at 9.26.22 PM1750×1000 158 KB

The intent for this design was to make a small and nimble chassis. It is all 1/16" wall tubing, it could even run 3.25" wheels if you wanted (though we would not) and it is a bit under max frame perimeter size (28x28). It is set up to run 25 chain, with the option to go chain in tube or not. On this chassis it was not worth sacrificing wheelbase to get the gearboxes in the corner, so it is only center options. The bearing blocks have configurable drop (though you can’t change it in the assembly, we aren’t that fancy) but you don’t have much leeway if chain in tube. We have it built at .1 drop total.

The 6" Wheel Chassis

Screen Shot 2022-01-04 at 9.27.45 PM1900×1088 953 KB

This is our more rugged chassis that we would use if there were field obstacles that needed to be traversed. It also has the ability to be more flexible due to the wheel diameter. This design is mostly 1/8" wall tube, closer to max frame perimeter but a little longer than wide, can run 6 or 8 wheel drive, gearbox on any wheel, utilizes the same bearing blocks as the first chassis, and should* be able to run 25 or 35 chain in most configurations (*this should be mostly true, but there are some scenarios where gearbox placement is limited depending on chain used and wheel count). We sacrificed a tiny bit of wheelbase to be able to use both gearboxes in the corner, but it was worth it. For these 3 motor gearboxes we ended up making new shafts to replace the original 3/8 hex shaft on the first stage. We switched over to 1/2" hex with turned down 3/8 round ends so we can run all steel gears (we try to run all steel and pocketed gears for our gearboxes whenever possible).

Here is the public onshape document for them. The document is not going to be the cleanest ever but its mostly all there. There is also a lot of extras in the assemblies that were trial parts and not actually used, especially for the bumper attaching.

What we have learned (so far)
Both these chassis have been built, but we don’t have much time actually using them. That said there are a few things that could be done differently. First is the battery mount, it is not easy to take it battery out of this style mount, and we should have made the mount have two hole patterns so it would have worked on both chassis easily, but the 4" chassis was made before we finished the 6" design so here we are. Second, the multi piece belly pan was a good idea for sake of modularity on the 6" chassis, and we could have implemented that on the 4", but it does allow for a little sag at the seams. Third, the 4" chassis has bumper rail plates that were originally designed around custom tube plugs (before WCP released them) so the design needs to be updated for those. In the same vein, the 6" chassis bumpers use a WCP 1x1 tube plug for the bumper rail, and they are designed to be used backwards. An oversight on our part, because the printed plastic sleeve protrudes out the back, so we had to sand them off to install.

I don’t have many pictures of these as they are built, and none with both of them finished, but I will try to add them to this thread soon. If you have any questions about these or the design choices ask away!

Very cool! I really like what you did with the bumper rail “wings” to make them flush with the front of the frame.

Curious about the bumper “pins” you have on the 6" wheel chassis, and especially what the purpose is of this “Part 1” that shows up in one of the 3 locations. Did you build the bumpers to competition spec and test this out, or is the bumper mounting theoretical at this point?

image707×604 111 KB

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-05T03:44:27.863Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":310,"readers_count":309,"score":117.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398708,"topic_slug":"team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad","display_username":"Nuttyman54","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/c/e/ce2b9495707e101c43b2671f06c02df5a0d073e0.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Design and Strategy Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad/398708/3","custom_user_title":"Design and Strategy Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985314,"name":"Gregory S. ","username":"Gregory78","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gregory78/{size}/73219_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-05T15:12:36.327Z","cooked":"
Nuttyman54:

Very cool! I really like what you did with the bumper rail “wings” to make them flush with the front of the frame.

Thank you, we are pretty happy with that solution. We knew we wanted the front to be flush and had seen similar things done before, but most of the time it was on drivetrains that didn’t have the side tubes extending all the way to the front/back.

Nuttyman54:

Curious about the bumper “pins” you have on the 6" wheel chassis, and especially what the purpose is of this “Part 1” that shows up in one of the 3 locations. Did you build the bumpers to competition spec and test this out, or is the bumper mounting theoretical at this point?

image707×604 111 KB

So these are part of the trial pieces that haven’t been implemented yet. Those “pins” would be 3/8 tube and fixed to the bumper. The bumper rail would have the corresponding holes in them to accept these “pins”, which would prevent the bumper from moving up and down and front to back. They would work in conjunction with the thumb screw mount that you may have seen, in order to fasten the bumper and prevent them from pulling off. This potential solution was trying to locate the bumpers securely, and allow for a simple and quick bumper change, but not stick out the top (if for some reason it was important, say 2019 airship). We were also trying to prevent using an attachment method that relies on screwing into the bumper portion repeatedly, like putting a threaded insert or captive nut in, and using a thumb screw through the tube similar to the “pins”.

Alternatively you see a top mount bracket with the quick release draw slide latches, which we have had good luck with, and also speculate using for these bumpers. If we try out the “pin” style I will report back with our thoughts.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-05T15:12:36.327Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":239,"readers_count":238,"score":87.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398708,"topic_slug":"team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad","display_username":"Gregory S. ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":10762,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad/398708/4","custom_user_title":"78 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985327,"name":"Yair Kornblau","username":"Korny","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/korny/{size}/270694_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-05T16:18:09.629Z","cooked":"

These look really good! I do have some reservations about the chain runs in the 6" chassis. While having only one chain out of the gearbox does save some space inside the gearbox, it also “triple-loads” that chain, because it carries the force required for 3 wheels instead of one(the same for the next chain up, except it carries for 2). This could cause some issues with degradation and maintenance (also, tensioning these chain runs isn’t ideal because one sprocket’s location affects the next). I would suggest having three long chain runs directly from the gearbox to each wheel. While it is less space/weight-efficient, I believe it is the better choice.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-05T16:18:09.629Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":198,"readers_count":197,"score":59.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398708,"topic_slug":"team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad","display_username":"Yair Kornblau","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39034,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1690 Strategy/Mechanical design mentor"},"post_url":"/t/team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad/398708/5","custom_user_title":"1690 Strategy/Mechanical design mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985330,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-05T16:28:28.855Z","cooked":"

To add onto this, if the chain on the gearbox breaks (the one that is also likely to experience the highest loads), you drop to only one wheel driven on that side. By having individual runs of chain to each wheel, you add redundancy and reduce the loads on each individual chain. All of this at the cost of some space and weight mind you.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-05T16:28:28.855Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":78.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398708,"topic_slug":"team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":39034,"username":"Korny","name":"Yair Kornblau","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/korny/{size}/270694_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad/398708/6","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985337,"name":"TD78","username":"TD78","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/5f9b8f/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-05T17:10:16.208Z","cooked":"

Does this matter if it’s #25 chain or #35 chain? That 6" chassis has #35 chain. I certainly wouldnt do it with #25…would run individual loops to each wheel from the gearbox.

Definitely hearing the recommendation though.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-05T17:10:16.208Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":182,"readers_count":181,"score":126.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398708,"topic_slug":"team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad","display_username":"TD78","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/tag/25","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19532,"username":"cad321","name":"Brian Wagg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1107,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad/398708/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985339,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-05T17:14:19.102Z","cooked":"

Personally I’d probably be comfortable running your current setup with #35. Been a long while since I’ve seen #35 break in FRC (if ever… ). The #25 though is definitely where I’d be concerned.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-01-05T17:14:19.102Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":177,"readers_count":176,"score":40.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398708,"topic_slug":"team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/tag/25","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":1107,"username":"TD78","name":"TD78","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/5f9b8f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/team-78-offseason-wcd-mule-chassis-cad/398708/8","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985384,"name":"Yair Kornblau","username":"Korny","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/korny/{size}/270694_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-05T20:13:46.891Z","cooked":"

While I do agree that #35 chain is not likely to break in FRC conditions, we have broken a few in 2016 on a similar setup (smaller loops between wheels) which is how we learned these lessons. On that drive train there was also something a bit off with the sprocket alignment, but still, especially when obstacles are concerned(where the front wheel gets a pretty large impact and has to transmit a lot of force) I would go for the safer setup
The redundancy benefit definitely does play a role as well, 2016 Einstein semis 2 shows exactly what a failure mode looks like and it isn’t very pretty

I like that bumper system a lot. It is a sturdier version of what we have been doing for years. Those small adjustable crash guards are slick! I would be a little tentative to screw the snap latch plates into the top of the plywood like you have shown, but I guess if the majority of the shear action is stopped by the pins it wont matter much anyway. Slick design, great job guys!
